The last one has to do with regulation, which is the business of Coimisiún na Meán.

I have a question on reporters being able to trace people's identities online. What does that traceable element look like? Everybody on this side of the table has been abused by anonymous posters numerous times.

If social media platforms were treated as publications, it would put the onus on them to ensure that they do not have libellous or inflammatory content on their sites. We felt that some people might like to be able to post anonymously in support groups and other forums, but if the social media platforms have the identity of the person, they can trace the post. It is up to the social media companies to figure out how they are going to do that. We did not get that far. They will possibly have to be made do it.

It is interesting that Instagram has a full page advertisement in the Irish Times today that states it is going to start protecting minors and that parental permission will have to be sought. The citizens were concerned about how much we can trust the platforms that are making money out of us and have allowed this to happen for so long. Some of the resolutions call for legislation to strengthen the powers of Coimisiún na Meán. That is a matter for the committee.
There is also probably an EU element to this as well. That would be very important for the presentation to the EU.
Deputy Crowe is welcome to the committee.

I am not a member of this committee and am not ordinarily here so I thank the Chair for allowing me to contribute. Dr. Day is from my alma mater and is very welcome. Deputy Willie O'Dea sends an apology as he planned to be here. The witnesses have done a huge body of important work.

I want their opinions on a few issues. One is citizen journalists. It is a term I scoff at as I think people have to go and study to acquire the skills to be a journalist. The witnesses also said that there should not be opinion polling in the week before elections. That is not a bad suggestion. Has this been trialled in any jurisdictions? In election people are politically or personally aligned to candidates but there are also a lot of people who are undecided. In the last week some of them for whatever reason will go on the winning side. It could change mindsets. Pages such as Wikipedia start off with the day a person is born, who they are married to, their children and what their is career is. However, for most public figures, be they involved in politics, entertainment or any other form of public life, there is usually a little column on controversies towards the bottom of the page and they are not always accurate. It is very difficult to get them changed. Have the witnesses considered the issue of defamatory stuff that lingers online and is hard to remove?

The issue of citizen journalists is not a new phenomenon. Kate Adie famously said in her heyday that if she was looking for brain surgery, she would rather go to a brain surgeon rather than someone she met at a bus stop.

I agree with that as well. However, the citizens' parliament discussed, and was very taken by the experts who came in to talk about, community media and local media on a micro-scale. There were resolutions that called for community media to be financed through Government but for the funding to be disbursed by local county councils and local authorities, which would know the media in the locality. That would be a way of making some kind of compromise, where there would be some regulation and some adherence to the basic standards that would be expected. I do not know whether that answers the Deputy's question.

With regard to the opinion poll, I am not aware of any place that has been able to impose a ban on opinion polls, certainly not on digital media. Ms McInerney talked about the difficulty of feeding the beast of digital newsfeeds. Opinion polls are a very handy way of doing that, so I do not see them disappearing soon, but it is a stated problem the citizens' parliament identified, which it would like somebody to do something about.
The Deputy's last question was to do with change.
It was about the likes of these Wikipedia pages where content stays there.

Ms Ní Cheallaigh's point was about whether it would be possible in some way, shape or form, even by using different words, for social media posts to be regulated in the same way that publications are treated. That would deal with a lot of it. On traceability and identifiability, the name of the person would not necessarily have to be on the post, but the social media platform would take action immediately. That is part of the difficulty, as members have all experienced. People get these abusive posts and things that are proven to be absolutely false but are not taken down, even though the platform recognises that they are such. We had that with Twitter just recently. There is a need for stronger regulations and stronger laws from EU to national level. There is also a need for education that is particularly strong in the media literacy part, so people are more critical of the news they consume, are looking for different sources and cross-checking, as well as more strengthened funding being given to community media as a third pillar and balance to the other forces.
Mr. Mahon might like to address the fact that we spoke about how education should be across the board. He may explain a little more about that.

The citizens' parliament was made up of 20 citizens. It was a diverse sample with both young and old. Nearly everybody felt a certain inability to discriminate between what is good and bad media. We felt that campaigns were needed across the board, not just in schools, concerning basic fact-checking and learning about AI, which is a big thing now. While it is ever evolving, it is something we need to be looking at constantly.
That is one of the most important points made in this session.
Especially for non-digital natives - people like us. That is not Mr. Mahon, obviously.
Does Mr. Mahon have any suggestions in relation to that?
No, just kind of the-----
It is so obvious. I have a child who is nearly 14 and a 15-year-old. The difference between what is real and not real, and what is actually journalism and not journalism, but is just some-----

Maybe because we are exposed to it more we might be slightly more aware, but education does not just stop when people leave school. Something that was highlighted for us was there need to be campaigns that reach everybody, not just in schools.

I am acting as a filter. My kids come to me to ask whether something is true and, generally speaking, it is not. I say they cannot just trust anyone who is putting up any old theory online. There is no filter. How we create those filters into the future will be a critical issue.

On that point, just short of 50 years ago, as an experiment in our school, a series of classes on media studies were introduced that were not on the curriculum. We all took an interest. The person delivering it was interested in computers. At that stage, I found it so useful to be able to look at different stories from different perspectives. In this day and age, every child, from the age of four onwards, needs to have those critical faculties encouraged, not just in terms of social media but in terms of everything that is happening, especially with the advent of AI. I welcome the fact that was looked at.

As a student teacher, I am well aware of the difficulties schools face in designing a curriculum that is relevant, but it is certainly something that is needed. It is about making sure that our curriculums are up to date and teaching people the skills they need.
It is a very good topic. It is something we might come back to as part of our online safety and online misinformation discussions, which will start over the next few weeks.

As somebody who teachers media and communication studies at third level, which I have been doing for over 30 years, it still appals me that media studies is not a core part of the curriculum at primary and secondary school level and then, as Mr. Mahon said, for the general public. It is a basic literacy. It is as basic as maths and being able to read and write in your own language. It is just critical thinking-----
It is very thought-provoking. It is something-----
If we can help in any way in that-----

We have a transition year, at least, which is not as structured in terms of the curriculum. Even at that stage, it is not too late because we all can learn how to be critical, but the earlier the better.

I will add that it is important we do not forget that the older generation also needs to be included in media literacy. A lot of older people are being caught in the whirlwinds and are believing what they are reading and seeing. That is where the citizens-----
All the scammers.
Yes. The citizens' parliament came to this that from the very beginning to the very end of life, everybody should have a media literacy.
Yes. It is not just in schools.
No, not just in schools. It is across the board.

This is my personal opinion, and we did not really talk about this, but this could tap into parenting skills as well. As the Cathaoirleach said, his children come to him. It is great they can do that, but a lot of parents are very happy to hand out phones to young kids and leave them to figure it all out by themselves. We need to have more education on that because if kids did not have access to this stuff in the first place, maybe they would not need to be learning about media literacy at such a young age.
The modern-day babysitter is the phone.

Ms Ní Cheallaigh made a very good point. I thank the witnesses for being here. That concludes our public engagements for today. We will go into private session to deal with some housekeeping matters just after our witnesses leave.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee went into private session at 2.27 p.m. and adjourned at 2.46 p.m. until 12.30 p.m. on Wednesday, 12 November 2025.
